item.title: Structure of a Web Service
item.description:
MetaMatrix Web services are data services - they connect relational or XML data sources to XML output. While they may be created in different ways, all MetaMatrix Web services share some common features:
1. One or more Relational Sources that describe where the data is coming from.
2. XSD Schemas defining the XML formats for the Web service operation's input and output arguments. These will comprise the bodies of the request and response SOAP messages when the Web service is executed.
3. An XML View Model that describes the relationship between the XML format of the Web service operation's output argument and the Relational Source models.
4. A Web service Model that names the Web service and defines the individual Web service operations. Each Web service operation is linked to the input XML Schema, the output XML Schema, and the output XML View model.
5. A WSDL (Web Services Description Language) file that describes the interface to the users of the Web service.
Press "Click to Complete" button below to read the next step.

item.title: Source materials
item.description:
Web services can be created from different starting points. You will need one or more of the following pieces of information:
1. Source Connection Information
2. XSD Schemas
3. WSDL files
